citation.article-title: Burkholderia thailandensis sp. nov., a Burkholderia pseudomallei-like species.

p.s: Description of Burkholderia thailandensis sp. nov.
Burkholderia thailandensis (thai.lan.den'sis. M.L. adj. thailandensis pertaining to Thailand from where the organism was originally isolated)
Cells are Gram-negative and motile due to the presence of a polar tuft of two to four flagella.
The organism is nutritionally diverse and grows at temperatures ranging from 25 to 42°C.

The production of siderophore, lipase, lecithinase and protease are apparent at both 25 and 37°C (2). B. thailandensis colonies are smooth and glossy with a pink pigmentation on modified Ashdown's selective medium while B. pseudomallei colonies are rough and wrinkled with a dark purple pigmentation (2).
The API 20NE and API 50CH biochemical profiles for B. thailandensis strains are similar to those for B. pseudomallei strains (22).
Notable exceptions, however, include the capacity to assimilate L-arabinose, 5-keto-gluconate and adonitol and the inability to utilize erythritol and dulcitol as sole carbon sources.
Previous studies describing the presence of B. thailandensis during epidemiological surveys in Thailand have been unable to correlate human disease with this organism (22).

These findings support our animal studies which clearly demonstrate that B. thailandensis strains are avirulent for Syrian golden hamsters (2). B. thailandensis isolates are resistant to aminoglycosides but sensitive to tetracycline, ceftazidime and trimethoprim.
The type strain, E264, was isolated from a rice field soil sample in central Thailand (16).
The type strain has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection as ATCC 700388.
